title: Corporate Governance Practices of Macy's Inc

content.text: Macy's Inc has a diverse and experienced board of directors. As of [latest available date], the board consists of [number] members. The board is composed of directors with diverse backgrounds, expertise, and skills, including retail industry experience, finance, marketing, and technology. This composition ensures a well-rounded perspective on key business decisions and strategic planning. The board also includes a mix of independent and non-independent directors, providing a balance of perspectives and reducing potential conflicts of interest.

Macy's Inc follows a structured approach to executive compensation. The company's executive compensation program is designed to align executive interests with shareholder value creation and promote long-term company performance. The key components of executive compensation include base salary, annual cash incentives, and long-term equity incentives such as stock options and restricted stock units. The company emphasizes performance-based incentives tied to specific financial and non-financial targets, ensuring executives are rewarded for achieving predetermined goals. The compensation committee, comprised of independent directors, oversees the executive compensation program to ensure it remains competitive and aligned with best practices.

Macy's Inc actively engages with its shareholders to understand their concerns and gather feedback. The company holds regular shareholder meetings where investors can raise questions and express their views. Macy's Inc also utilizes various communication channels, such as investor relations websites and annual reports, to provide shareholders with timely and transparent information. The company recognizes the importance of shareholder input and considers it in its decision-making processes, enhancing accountability and transparency.

Macy's Inc has established several board committees to oversee specific areas of governance and provide focused expertise. These committees include the audit committee, compensation committee, finance committee, and nominating and corporate governance committee. Each committee is composed of independent directors who possess relevant expertise in their respective areas. The committees meet regularly to review and recommend actions to the full board, ensuring thorough oversight in key areas of corporate governance.

Macy's Inc places a strong emphasis on ethics and compliance. The company has implemented a comprehensive code of conduct that outlines expected behaviors and ethical standards for employees and directors. The code of conduct covers topics such as conflicts of interest, confidentiality, anti-bribery and anti-corruption, data privacy, and diversity and inclusion. Macy's Inc also maintains a robust compliance program to identify and mitigate risks related to legal and regulatory requirements. The company regularly trains employees on ethics and compliance and provides channels for reporting potential violations or concerns.

Macy's Inc engages an independent auditing firm to perform annual audits and ensure the accuracy and transparency of its financial statements. The external auditors not only review the financial records but also evaluate the effectiveness of internal controls and risk management processes. This independent oversight helps maintain the integrity of the company's financial reporting and provides assurance to shareholders and stakeholders.

Macy's Inc demonstrates strong corporate governance practices with a diverse and experienced board, structured executive compensation program, active shareholder engagement, established board committees, focus on ethics and compliance, and engagement with external auditors. These practices contribute to accountability, transparency, and the long-term success of the company.

news.headline: Arkhouse and Brigade up Macy's takeover offer to $6.6 billion following rejection of previous deal
news.summary: Arkhouse Management and Brigade Capital Management are upping their offer to acquire Macy's in a deal now valued at $6.6 billion.  The investment firms announced Sunday that they had submitted an all-cash proposal of $24 for each of the remaining shares in Macy's they don't already own — up from a earlier offer of $21 per share.  Macy's rejected the previous deal, which was valued at $5.8 billion, in January.

news.headline: UPDATE 2-Arkhouse, Brigade raise Macy's buyout bid to $6.6 bln
news.summary: Arkhouse Management, a real-estate-focused investing firm said on Sunday it and Brigade Capital Management have raised their offer for Macy's after the department store chain rebuffed their prior proposal as too low.  The firms are now offering to acquire Macy's stock they don't already own for $24 per share, about 14% more than its previous offer of $21 per share.  "The Macy's Inc Board will carefully review and evaluate the latest proposal," Macy's said in a separate statement.

news.headline: Arkhouse, Brigade raise Macy's buyout bid to $6.6 billion
news.summary: The firms are now offering to acquire Macy's stock they don't already own for $24 per share, about 14% more than its previous offer of $21 per share.  "The Macy's Inc Board will carefully review and evaluate the latest proposal," Macy's said in a separate statement.  The two investment firms had submitted a proposal in December last year to acquire the shares of Macy's they don't already own for $21 a share but the offer was rejected by the department store operator due to concerns over the deal's financing and valuation.
